description: From Latin patefactio, from patefacere (“to open”), from patere (“to lie open”) + facere (“to make”).

entries.meaning: The act of opening, disclosing, or manifesting; open declaration.
examples: All revelation is reduced to the patefaction of God in the series of His great redemptive acts, to the exclusion—entire or partial—of revelation by word, which is sometimes represented, indeed, as in the nature of the case impossible.
